title: 105_s314
content: There is no text provided in the prev_chunk, so I cannot generate a condensed text chunk for the curr_chunk. The "Federal Activities Inventory Reform Act of 1998" requires executive agencies to submit lists of non-inherently governmental activities annually to the Office of Management and Budget, including details like the fiscal year of appearance, employee numbers, and responsible personnel. The "Federal Activities Inventory Reform Act of 1998" mandates executive agencies to submit lists of non-inherently governmental activities annually to the Office of Management and Budget. The Director of OMB reviews and consults with agency heads on the final list, which must be made public and transmitted to Congress. Any changes to the list must also be promptly shared with the public and Congress. The executive agency must use a competitive process when considering contracting with a private sector source for activities on the list. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will provide guidance for this process. Cost comparisons for contracting with a private sector source must be realistic and fair. When deciding whether to contract with a private sector source for an executive agency activity, the head of the agency must compare costs and ensure all expenses are considered, including quality assurance, monitoring, insurance, benefits, and overhead costs. SEC. 3. CHALLENGES TO THE LIST. An interested party can challenge the omission or inclusion of an activity on a published list. Interested parties include private sector sources, business associations, and executive agency employees with a direct economic interest in the activity. An interested party can challenge the omission or inclusion of an activity on a published list within 30 days of its availability. The executive agency must decide on the challenge within 28 days and provide a written notification with the rationale. The party has the right to appeal the decision to the head of the executive agency. An interested party can appeal an adverse decision of the official to the head of the executive agency within 10 days. The head of the executive agency must decide on the appeal within 10 days and provide a written notification with the rationale for the decision. SEC. 4. APPLICABILITY. This Act applies to executive agencies including executive departments, military departments, and independent establishments, with exceptions for the General Accounting Office, Government corporations, certain nonappropriated funds instrumentalities, and depot-level maintenance and repair of the Department of Defense. Depot-level maintenance and repair of the Department of Defense falls under the provisions of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "Federal Government source" refers to any executive agency organization using Federal Government employees for an activity. An "inherently governmental function" is a function requiring performance by Federal Government employees, involving discretion in applying authority or making value judgments for the government, including decisions on monetary transactions and entitlements. The term "inherently governmental function" refers to activities that bind the United States, protect its interests, affect private individuals, control government officers, or manage federal funds. It excludes functions like gathering information or providing advice. The term "inherently governmental function" excludes functions like gathering information or providing advice to federal government officials. It also excludes ministerial and internal functions such as building security, mail operations, and housekeeping. The Act will be effective on October 1, 1998.
